p: Some earlier studies also reported the enhancement of α-tocopherol along with temperature till 60 °C in convective drying ( Laoretani et al., 2014; Al Juhaimi et al., 2018). This may be due to the stability of γ-tocopherol methyltransferase enzyme which converts γ- and δ-tocopherols into α- and β-tocopherols at ambient and/or higher temperature (<50 °C) ( Shigeoka et al., 1992). While in BF, the change in the amount of α- and β-tocopherol was insignificant with respect to BP, which may be explained as, the optimum temperature for γ-tocopherol methyltransferase is about 40 °C, at a lower temperature the enzyme may be deactivated ( Gálvez-Valdivieso et al., 2011) as well as the reaction kinetics may be impacted in lower temperature. However, the actual reaction mechanism is yet to be revealed. As some of the earlier studies reported opposite trends also for α-tocopherol in jujube fruit and Moringa oleifera leaves drying ( Gao et al., 2012; Saini et al., 2014).
